Award.AwardTitle: A Novel Bi-Enzyme System for Amperometric Biosensing of Plant Volatiles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1159540
Ramasamy

The goal of this project is to develop an electrochemical biosensing system to detect a volatile
compound released by plants. The volatile chemical signature of plants carries unique
information that can be helpful in the identification of the state-of-heath of the plant. Detection of
this signature can advance our understanding of the ?plant language? and will eventually help in
the development of real-time health monitoring systems for large-scale agriculture. The
proposed work integrates material science, biochemistry and electrochemistry to develop a
nanostructured platform for amperometric biosensing. Successful completion of the proposed
work will result in a novel bi-enzyme based electrochemical biosensor with tunable properties.
The hybrid composite nanomaterial interfaces to be developed in this project will provide
multiple benefits and can be applied to other bio-electrochemical systems. The proposed work
will directly impact the field of agriculture and forestry. The project will also have broader
influence in the development of enzyme-based biosensors. The proposed project will provide
education and training for graduate and undergraduate students and post-docs. Results from
the project will be broadly disseminated through conference presentations, seminars and
scientific publications. The proposed outreach activities will provide a social impact on the high
school students in the state of Georgia.

Institution.Name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported by the NSF grant # 1159540 was focused on the development of novel sensing technology for the detection of disease indicative plant volatile chemical marker based on fundamental studies involving bioelectrochemistry, materials science and nanotechnology. The project was headed by Principal Investigator (PI) Ramaraja Ramasamy. The project directly supported the dissertation work of a doctoral student Yi Fang who is expected to graduate by the end of Fall 2016. The project has been successfully completed by June 2016 and most of the originally proposed goals have been achieved. The project resulted in the development of two different methods of amperometric biosensing for highly selective detection of methyl salicylate with desirable levels of sensitivity and detection limits.

Intellectual Merit: The work accomplished in this project integrated material science, plant biochemistry, electrochemistry and nanoscale science and technology towards the development of a novel non-invasive technology for early detection of stressed plants through analysis of their volatile signature in order to identify target markers. The accomplished work provides a fundamental understanding of the principles behind the multi-enzyme cascade reactions and their implications for biosensing applications. The materials science knowledge developed in this work could be broadly applied to the development of other bio-nanocomposite based interfaces for a variety of end applications.

Broader Impact: The work accomplished in this project would directly benefit the field of agriculture by introducing a new technology for rapid and early detection of plant diseases. Pest and pathogen induced losses to the agricultural industry are estimated at over $20 billion dollars annually. The currently used methods in plant disease detection are cumbersome, require skilled labor and are time consuming. The technology highlighted in this project could serve to provide a viable alternative to the existing technologies for early detection of crop diseases in agriculture. The scientific concepts could be broadly applied to other areas including environmental toxicology and medicine. The project has supported one full time graduate student (Ph.D.) for over 3 years, 2 part time graduate students, a technician and a post-doc over the course of 4 years. The Ph.D. student who worked in this project is expected to defend his dissertation in Fall 2016. The findings from this project have been broadly disseminated in scientific journals and professional conferences. The project also provided multiple levels of experiential learning for undergraduate students, graduate students and post-docs. The bio-electrochemistry BCHE 4180/6710 course developed by the PI incorporated several lab modules that provide hands-on experimental experience for both undergraduate and graduate biochemical engineering students at UGA.

The project findings including experimental methods, results and observations have been documented in the laboratory notebooks possessed by the University of Georgia and held in the PI’s lab. The findings have also been published in five scientific journal articles and a number of professional conferences. 

 


Last Modified: 09/21/2016
Modified by: Ramaraja P Ramasamy
